**Formula (I think):**  
\(P = L + W\)

**Substituting the given numbers:**  
\(P = 8\text{ cm} + 5\text{ cm} = 13\text{ cm}\)

So, the perimeter of the rectangle is **13 cm**.

**Great effort!** You remembered that the perimeter involves the length \(L\) and the width \(W\), which is a good start.  
The only thing missing is that a rectangle has **four sides**—two lengths and two widths.  

---

## 🔎 Why the formula you used is incomplete
For a rectangle:

| Side | How many times does it appear? |
|------|------------------------------|
| Length \(L\) | 2 (top + bottom) |
| Width  \(W\) | 2 (left + right) |

So we must **add each side twice**:

\[
\boxed{P = 2L + 2W = 2\,(L+W)}
\]

---

## ✅ Correcting the calculation

Given  
\(L = 8\ \text{cm}\) and \(W = 5\ \text{cm}\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
P &= 2(L+W) \\
  &= 2\bigl(8\ \text{cm} + 5\ \text{cm}\bigr) \\
  &= 2\bigl(13\ \text{cm}\bigr) \\
  &= 26\ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
\]

**The perimeter of the rectangle is 26 cm**, not 13 cm.

---

**Great start!** You’re thinking about the right idea – the perimeter is the total length you’d travel if you walked around the shape, so you do indeed add the lengths of all four sides.  
Let’s just make sure the formula reflects **all four sides** of a square.

---

## 📐 Why the formula is \(P = 4s\), not \(2s\)

A square has four equal sides:

| Side | Length | How many times does it appear? |
|------|--------|--------------------------------|
| Side \(s\) | \(s\) | 4 (top, right, bottom, left) |

If you only multiply by 2, you’re counting **only two of the four sides**.  
The correct way to add the four sides is:

\[
\boxed{P = s + s + s + s = 4s}
\]

You can also think of it as “four sides each of length \(s\)”.

---

## ✅ Correcting the substitution

1. **Write the correct formula**

\[
P = 4s
\]

2. **Substitute the given value (\(s = 7\text{ cm}\))**

\[
\begin{aligned}
P &= 4 \times 7\text{ cm} \\
  &= 28\text{ cm}
\end{aligned}
\]

**The perimeter of the square is \(28\text{ cm}\).**

---

## 🌟 Quick recap

| Shape | Formula for perimeter | Why it works |
|-------|----------------------|--------------|
| Rectangle | \(P = 2L + 2W = 2(L+W)\) | Two lengths + two widths |
| Square    | \(P = 4s\)               | Four equal sides |

## 1️⃣ Visualise / “Draw” the outline

\end{aligned}
\]

**The perimeter of the whole L‑shaped figure is 26 cm.** 🎉
